header.title: Magical Interpretations, Material Realities: Modernity, Witchcraft and the Occult in Postcolonial Africa

central_thesis: The central thesis of this collection is that "witchcraft" and other occult practices in postcolonial Africa are not static, "traditional" remnants, but rather dynamic, modern phenomena deeply intertwined with, and often acting as critiques of, contemporary socio-economic transformations, global capitalism, and prevailing notions of modernity. The book argues against Western teleological views that predict the disappearance of such beliefs with progress, demonstrating their persistent relevance as local communities grapple with new forms of power, wealth, and insecurity.

structure_content.chapter_title: 1 Magical interpretations and material realities: an introduction
structure_content.summary: This introductory chapter sets the stage by challenging the Western social evolutionary notion that witchcraft and occult beliefs would disappear with modernity. It argues that witchcraft in Africa is a modern phenomenon, dynamically engaged with contemporary social, economic, and political changes, and not reducible to a simplistic 'primitive' category. It emphasizes contextualizing 'witchcraft' beyond Western definitions and highlights the book's focus on the varied meanings and practices across different African societies.

structure_content.chapter_title: 2 Delusions of development and the enrichment of witchcraft discourses in Cameroon
structure_content.summary: Francis B. Nyamnjoh explores how Western epistemological exports have often mischaracterized African realities. He argues that in Cameroon, popular epistemology marries natural and supernatural, rational and irrational, visible and invisible. Witchcraft is central to understanding development failures and illicit accumulation, reflecting collective anxieties about unbridled individualism and external exploitation, often manifesting as concerns over corrupt political leaders using occult means for power.

structure_content.chapter_title: 3 Cannibal transformations: colonialism and commodification in the Sierra Leone hinterland
structure_content.summary: Rosalind Shaw historicizes cannibalism stories in Sierra Leone, tracing their evolution from pre-colonial memories of the Atlantic slave trade to colonial perceptions of Human Leopards and Crocodiles, and eventually to postcolonial rumors about political elites. She demonstrates how these images of 'extractive relationships' continuously adapt to changing forms of commodification and power, serving as a critical commentary on historical and contemporary socio-economic exploitation.

structure_content.chapter_title: 4 Vulture men, campus cultists and teenaged witches: modern magics in Nigerian popular media
structure_content.summary: Misty L. Bastian analyzes Nigerian popular press narratives about 'modern magics,' including human-animal transformations ('vulture men'), university 'cultism,' and 'teenaged witches.' These narratives reflect urban anxieties about anonymity, social change, gender roles, and the erosion of civility in the face of late capitalism and state corruption. Witchcraft is portrayed as a dynamic force, often glamorized or used as a means of agency by young women challenging patriarchal norms.

structure_content.chapter_title: 5 Witchcraft and scepticism by proxy: Pentecostalism and laughter in urban Malawi
structure_content.summary: Rijk van Dijk examines how Pentecostalism in urban Malawi offers a unique lens through which to understand witchcraft. He shows that while Pentecostal ideology rigorously combats witchcraft as satanic, it also creates a space for 'scepticism by proxy' and laughter, particularly among youths challenging gerontocratic authority. Witchcraft confessions and cleansing rituals become sites for negotiating modern identities and critiquing both 'traditional' and 'modern' forms of power.

structure_content.chapter_title: 6 Black market, free market: anti-witchcraft shrines and fetishes among the Akan
structure_content.summary: Jane Parish investigates anti-witchcraft shrines among the Akan of Ghana, highlighting how these shrines are integrated into debates about modern capitalism and wealth accumulation. Young marketeers use talismans for financial success and protection, blending local 'African spirits' with global commodities. In contrast, 'young aristocrats' criticize these shrines for promoting greed and 'evil magic,' advocating instead for a return to 'traditional' African values of community and morality.

structure_content.chapter_title: 7 Betrayal or affirmation? Transformations in witchcraft technologies of power, danger and agency among the Tuareg of Niger
structure_content.summary: Susan Rasmussen explores four types of ritual power among the Tuareg of Niger (togerchet, tezma, ark echaghel, al baraka), demonstrating their complex, ambivalent, and evolving meanings. She argues that these powers are invoked to explain human social destiny amidst socioeconomic turmoil, reflecting tensions between traditional social structures, gender roles, and the impacts of free market economics and state policies. Witchcraft beliefs illuminate local idioms of 'development' and resistance to global intrusions.

structure_content.chapter_title: 8 Save our skins: structural adjustment, morality and the occult in Tanzania
structure_content.summary: Todd Sanders examines how structural adjustment policies in Tanzania have fueled the proliferation of occult discourses, particularly rumors about human skin trafficking for wealth. He argues that these narratives serve as a local moral critique of capitalism and 'free market' ideologies, which are perceived as amoral and conducive to illicit accumulation. For Tanzanians, the occult provides a language to articulate concerns about social change, inequality, and the commodification of humanity in a globalized world.

structure_content.chapter_title: 9 Witchcraft in the new South Africa: from colonial superstition to postcolonial reality?
structure_content.summary: Isak Niehaus analyzes the Ralushai Commission's report on witchcraft violence in post-apartheid South Africa, arguing it marks a shift from colonial views of witchcraft as 'superstition' to an official recognition of it as a 'reality' and a marker of African identity. He discusses inconsistencies in colonial and apartheid-era legislation and how the new state's approach, while aiming to reduce violence, risks entrenching social inequality and problematic definitions of witchcraft.

structure_content.chapter_title: 10 On living in a world with witches: everyday epistemology and spiritual insecurity in a modern African city (Soweto)
structure_content.summary: Adam Ashforth explores spiritual insecurity in Soweto, South Africa, where witchcraft is understood as an illegitimate means to cause harm or accumulate wealth. He describes the epistemological challenges of discerning witchcraft's hidden motives and methods, highlighting how it exacerbates anxieties related to poverty, violence, and illness. Sowetans navigate a complex landscape of traditional healers, Christian churches, and a prevailing sense of malice, making life a constant struggle against unseen forces.

structure_content.chapter_title: 11 Witchcraft, development and paranoia in Cameroon: interactions between popular, academic and state discourse
structure_content.summary: Cyprian F. Fisiy and Peter Geschiere detail how 'development' policy initiatives in Cameroon inadvertently led to the study of witchcraft. They show how official state discourse initially framed witchcraft as an anti-developmental, leveling force. However, with the collapse of development projects and rising economic inequalities, witchcraft discourses evolved to emphasize its 'accumulative' side, linking it to the wealth of entrepreneurs and political elites, reflecting popular paranoia about illegitimate success.

key_concepts.definition: A dynamic, culturally embedded phenomenon in postcolonial Africa, often a 'social diagnostic' rather than a simple 'belief.' It is a complex set of discourses and practices related to morality, sociality, humanity, and power, which can be interpreted differently across contexts, encompassing both harmful and beneficial uses of mystical forces. It challenges Western definitions of 'primitive' or 'pre-logical' thinking.

Distinguished from witchcraft in earlier anthropological work as a conscious practice of evil magic, often deploying objects, 'medicines,' or 'tools.' In many African contexts, the distinction between witchcraft (innate power) and sorcery (learned magic) is blurred, and local terms may encompass both.

A more neutral term used by some anthropologists to describe mystical powers in Africa, leaving open whether the force is used for evil or good. These forces are understood as animating visible outcomes, shaping daily lives, and providing a compelling local lexicon for discussing morality, entitlement, and social change.

The concept that modernity is not a singular, unilinear trajectory dictated by Western ideals, but rather a pluralistic and culturally diverse set of experiences. This framework allows for understanding how African societies integrate and reinterpret global forces like capitalism and development in their own unique ways, often with occult beliefs as a constitutive element.

The notion that invisible forces and ritual practices are deeply intertwined with economic processes, particularly concerning wealth accumulation, market dynamics, and resource distribution. These economies often emerge as a local critique of global capitalism and structural adjustment, highlighting perceived injustices and illicit means of gaining wealth.

A Tuareg mystic power associated with 'evil eye/mouth,' caused by back-biting, envy, or complacent praise. It is believed to wound people and animals and underscores the cultural value of verbal restraint, caution, and avoiding ostentatious displays of success or belongings.

A smith-specific mystic power among the Tuareg, believed to be unintentionally activated. It targets the stomach, causing fatal swelling, particularly in children and animals, if one fails to compensate smiths justly or share surplus. It is linked to the breakdown of traditional reciprocal relations between nobles and smiths.

'Bad work' or sorcery among the Tuareg, considered a terrible force capable of killing from a distance. Its activation requires expert services, specific ingredients, and often curses drawn from Qur'anic verses. It highlights the complex and sometimes blurred boundaries between different ritual powers and their agents, including marabouts.

Islamic blessing or benediction, concentrated in prominent marabouts and chiefs, and associated with good fortune and fertility. While ideally benevolent, it is also ambiguously understood, as it can be misused or converted into 'bad work' (ark echaghel), especially in contexts of political and economic competition.

A highly diffuse and ambivalent notion of occult forces among the Maka people. It encompasses both negative (leveling, causing misfortune due to jealousy) and positive (accumulative, protecting wealth) aspects. It is seen as deeply intertwined with kinship, power dynamics, and the pursuit of individual success in modern contexts, often appearing amoral due to its fluid nature.

A mysterious world of abundance and infinite possibilities in the Bamenda Grassfields, described as a 'bazaar' where wealth is gained through human sacrifice ('goat' or 'fowl'). It is ambivalent, offering both good and evil, pleasure and pain. It is interpreted as analogous to modern capitalism's promises of emancipation alongside its harsh realities of exploitation and disenchantment.

A category of young women, often portrayed in Nigerian popular media, who confess to possessing mystical powers, sometimes from a 'spiritual husband' like Mami Wata. These powers are linked to overwhelming sexuality and reproductive blockage, used to ensnare and destroy men for material gain. Their confessions are often framed within Pentecostal exorcisms, reflecting anxieties about female agency and consumption in urban modernity.

practical_system.description: This book is an academic collection of essays, offering an anthropological analysis of witchcraft and occult practices in postcolonial Africa, rather than a practical manual or grimoire for operative magic. It describes how various African communities understand, engage with, and utilize different forms of mystical power in their daily lives, often in response to socio-economic and political changes. The 'operative side' discussed is primarily an ethnographic account of beliefs and observed practices.
tools: Herbs and roots (for traditional medicines, healing, protection, or malevolent magic)
Human body parts (skins, genitals, organs, blood, bones – believed to be used for powerful concoctions for wealth and power, particularly in 'occult economies')
Talismans and fetishes (protective charms, often combining natural ingredients with modern commodities like credit cards, to attract good fortune or defend against witchcraft)
Qur'anic verses and formulae (used by marabouts for amulets, healing, or sorcery)
Spirit pacts (agreements with spirits or supernatural entities for wealth or power, often requiring sacrifice)
Physical objects (mirrors, razor blades, sticks, plates, horns, ball pens, gramophone records – believed to be used by witches for their craft)
Modern commodities (cars, radios, plastic wares, foreign goods – seen as both products of and means to occult power, or as items used in occult transactions)
rituals: Divinations (e.g., by marabouts, traditional healers, Pentecostal prophets to diagnose illness, misfortune, or identify witches/sorcerers)
Sacrifices (animal sacrifices for beneficial transformations, human sacrifices believed to generate wealth or political power, often illicitly)
Witch-cleansing movements (e.g., mchape in Malawi, aimed at eradicating witchcraft and purifying communities)
Pentecostal exorcisms (practices to 'cast out' evil spirits and demons, often involving public confessions and prayer sessions)
Amulet preparation and wearing (for protection against malevolent forces, attracting wealth, or influencing others)
Rituals for maintaining kinship ties and community solidarity (contrasting with individualistic pursuits of occult power)
Ritual killings (to obtain body parts for powerful concoctions or spirit pacts, particularly in occult economies)

relevant_quotes.text: Witchcraft is alive and well in Africa today both among the disenchanted and downtrodden as well as the educated elite. This volume sets out recent thinking on witchcraft in Africa, paying particular attention to variations in meanings and practices. It examines the way different people in different contexts are making sense of what witchcraft is and what it might mean.

As societies 'evolved', a number of things allegedly happened: scientific understandings grew; instrumental rationality increased; a secular world view triumphed; 'superstitions' like witchcraft vanished; and people made an ever clearer distinction between facts and fictions, objective Truth and subjective falsehoods. Social evolutionary theory suggested that Europeans had somehow 'evolved' quite a bit further than had Africans or other 'primitives'.

Witchcraft and the occult in Africa are a set of discourses on morality, sociality and humanity: on human frailty. Far from being a set of irrational beliefs, they are a form of historical consciousness, a sort of social diagnostics.

The occultic is like the doctorate programme for young frat boys like us. While we learn the ropes within the school environment through regular fraternities, our fathers are consolidating our position in the big-time league pending our graduation. And it’s rather ridiculous to hear people suggest that our mothers do not know of our fathers’ involvement in secret societies. How the heck did they meet?…Why is society forever persecuting us?

Witchcraft is much worse today than ever before. . . . In the past people wanted only a few things. . . . Today there are too many things that people want. . . . cars, bicycles, radios, nice houses, etc. . . . Everyone wants to develop (kuendelea). But think about it. . . . How is this possible? People become jealous of what others around them have. Maybe that one has a radio and that one doesn’t, but he wants one. . . . He might be so angry that he bewitches the neighbour and his stupid radio. He might try to knock him down, to cause him to go backwards (kurudi nyuma) so that he will not develop. This is why today witchcraft is much worse. It is development itself that brings witchcraft. More development means more witchcraft.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book is highly relevant for understanding the complex interplay between traditional belief systems, modern socio-economic forces, and political dynamics in postcolonial Africa. It effectively deconstructs Western-centric notions of modernity and rationality, arguing that witchcraft is not an archaic relic but a vital lens through which Africans interpret and critique their changing world. The collection's comparative ethnographic approach reveals the diverse, yet interconnected, ways occult beliefs adapt to new contexts, offering profound insights into the human experience of globalization, inequality, and the moral dilemmas of modern life. It contributes significantly to critical development studies and the anthropology of religion by highlighting indigenous epistemologies.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This book targets academics and researchers in anthropology, sociology, African studies, religious studies, development studies, and political science. It is also valuable for policy makers, non-governmental organizations, and anyone interested in understanding contemporary African societies, the local impacts of globalization, and the evolving nature of occult beliefs in a rapidly changing world.
